title: Study Shows How COVID-19 Could Lead to Runaway Inflammation
description: Why do some people with COVID-19 develop severe inflammation? Spike protein structure offers a clue.
cleaned_text: [Cedars-Sinai](https://www.cedars-sinai.org/)addresses a mystery first raised in March: Why do some people with COVID-19 develop severe inflammation? The research shows how the molecular structure and sequence of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein—part of the virus that causes COVID-19—could be behind the inflammatory syndrome cropping up in infected patients. [Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences](https://www.pnas.org/content/early/2020/09/25/2010722117), uses computational modeling to zero in on a part of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that may act as a "superantigen," kicking the immune system into overdrive as in [toxic shock syndrome](https://www.cedars-sinai.org/health-library/diseases-and-conditions/t/toxic-shock-syndrome-tss.html)—a rare, life-threatening complication of bacterial infections. [Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children](http://www.cdc.gov/mis-c)(MIS-C), include persistent fever and severe inflammation that can affect a host of bodily systems. While rare, the syndrome can be serious or even fatal. [The first reports of this condition coming out of Europe caught the attention of study co-senior author](https://dam.upmc.com/-/media/upmc/media/publishingimages/2020/september/moshe-arditi-cedars-hr.jpg?la=en&rev=f35c9c73ea3345efb167b00392095d3a&hash=50AF999258B310CE27E94371518340DB) [Moshe Arditi, M.D.](https://bio.cedars-sinai.org/moshea/index.html), director of the Pediatric Infectious Diseases and Immunology Division at Cedars-Sinai and an expert on another pediatric inflammatory disease— [Kawasaki disease](https://www.cedars-sinai.org/health-library/diseases-and-conditions---pediatrics/k/kawasaki-disease.html). [Ivet Bahar, Ph.D.](https://www.csb.pitt.edu/people/faculty/ivet-bahar/), distinguished professor and John K. Vries Chair of computational and systems biology at Pitt School of Medicine, and the two started searching for features of the SARS-CoV-2 virus that might be responsible for MIS-C. [Bahar and her team created a computer model of the interaction between the SARS-CoV-2 viral spike protein and the receptors on human T cells, the foot soldiers of the immune system. Under normal circumstances, T cells help the body fight off infection, but when these cells are activated in abnormally large quantities, as is the case with superantigens, they produce massive amounts of inflammatory cytokines—small proteins involved in immune system signaling—in what's known as a "cytokine storm."](https://dam.upmc.com/-/media/upmc/media/publishingimages/2020/september/bahar-spike-sag-hr.jpg?la=en&rev=9e82320c9c5d40098ea75ada47e84444&hash=166A65CFC760285FEB66B947CEB9D8F2) ["Everything came one after another, each time a huge surprise. The pieces of the puzzle ended up fitting extremely well," said Bahar, co-senior author on and R01 as institutional funds. [Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg](http://www.uni-halle.de/).
